{{more citations needed|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox language |name = Aymara |nativename = ''Aymar aru'' |pronunciation = {{IPA-ay|ajmaɾ ˈaɾu|}} |states = [[Bolivia]], [[Peru]] and [[Chile]] |ethnicity = [[Aymara people]] |speakers = 1,677,100 |date = 2007-2011 |ref ={{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/ayr|title=Aymara, Central|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/ayc|title=Aymara, Southern|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}} |familycolor = American |fam1 = [[Aymaran languages|Aymaran]] |nation = {{flag|Bolivia}}
{{flag|Peru}}{{efn|Official only in Aymara–dominated areas.}} |minority = {{flag|Chile}} |iso1=ay |iso2=aym |iso3=aym |lc1=ayr |ld1=Central Aymara |lc2=ayc |ld2=Southern Aymara |glotto=nucl1667 |glottorefname=Nuclear Aymara |map=Aymara in South America.svg |mapcaption=Geographic Distribution of the Aymara language |notice=IPA }} '''Aymara''' ({{IPA-ay|ajˈma.ɾa|IPA|Ay_aymara_001.ogg}}; also {{lang|ay|Aymar aru}}) is an [[Aymaran languages|Aymaran]] language spoken by the [[Aymara people]] of the [[Andes]]. It is one of only a handful of [[Indigenous languages of the Americas|Native American languages]] with over one million speakers.{{cite web |title=Bolivia: Idioma Materno de la Población de 4 años de edad y más- UBICACIÓN, ÁREA GEOGRÁFICA, SEXO Y EDAD |work=2001 Bolivian Census |publisher=Instituto Nacional de Estadística, La Paz — Bolivia |url=http://www.ine.gov.bo/BEYOND/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=993 }}{{dead link| date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}The other native American languages with more than one million speakers are [[Nahuatl]], [[Quechua languages]], and [[Guarani language|Guaraní]]. Aymara, along with [[Spanish language|Spanish]], is one of the official languages of [[Bolivia]] and parts of [[Peru]]. It is also spoken, to a much lesser extent, by some communities in northern [[Chile]], where it is a [[Minority language|recognized minority language]]. Some linguists have claimed that Aymara is related to its more widely spoken neighbor, [[Quechua languages|Quechua]]. That claim, however, is disputed. Although there are indeed similarities, like the nearly-identical phonologies, the majority position among linguists today is that the similarities are better explained as [[areal feature (linguistics)|areal features]] rising from prolonged cohabitation, rather than natural genealogical changes that would stem from a common [[protolanguage]]. Aymara is an [[agglutinating language|agglutinating]] and, to a certain extent, a [[polysynthetic language]]. It has a [[subject–object–verb]] word order. == Etymology == The ethnonym "Aymara" may be ultimately derived from the name of some group occupying the southern part of what is now the Quechua speaking area of Apurímac.[[Willem Adelaar]] with [[Pieter Muysken]], ''Languages of the Andes'', CUP, Cambridge, 2004, pp 259 Regardless, the use of the word "Aymara" as a label for this people was standard practice as early as 1567, as evident from Garci Diez de San Miguel's report of his inspection of the province of Chucuito (1567, 14; cited in Lafaye 1964). In this document, he uses the term ''aymaraes'' to refer to the people. The language was then called [[Qulla people|Colla]]. It is believed that Colla was the name of an Aymara nation at the time of conquest, and later was the southernmost region of the Inca empire Collasuyu. However, [[Rodolfo Cerrón Palomino|Cerrón Palomino]] disputes this claim and asserts that Colla were in fact [[Puquina language|Puquina]] speakers who were the rulers of [[Tiwanaku]] in the first and third centuries (2008:246). This hypothesis suggests that the linguistically-diverse area ruled by the Puquina came to adopt Aymara languages in their southern region.{{Cite book |last=Coler |first=Matt |year=2015 |title=A Grammar of Muylaq' Aymara: Aymara as spoken in Southern Peru |series=Brill's Studies in the Indigenous Languages of the Americas |publisher=Brill |page=9 |isbn=978-9-00-428380-0}} In any case, the use of "Aymara" to refer to the language may have first occurred in the works of the lawyer, magistrate and tax collector in [[Potosí]] and [[Cusco]], Juan Polo de Ondegardo. This man, who later assisted Viceroy Toledo in creating a system under which the indigenous population would be ruled for the next 200 years, wrote a report in 1559 entitled ‘On the lineage of the Yncas and how they extended their conquests’{{source needed|date=July 2018}} in which he discusses land and taxation issues of the Aymara under the Inca empire. More than a century passed before "Aymara" entered general usage to refer to the language spoken by the Aymara people (Briggs, 1976:14). In the meantime the Aymara language was referred to as "the language of the Colla". The best account of the history of Aymara is that of Cerrón-Palomino, who shows that the ethnonym Aymara, which came from the glottonym, is likely derived from the Quechuaized toponym ''ayma-ra-y'' ‘place of communal property’. The entire history of this term is thoroughly outlined in his book, ''Voces del Ande'' (2008:19–32) and ''Lingüística Aimara''.[[Rodolfo Cerrón-Palomino]], ''Lingüística Aimara'', Centro de Estudios Regionales Andinos "Bartolomé de las Casas", Lima, 2000, pp 34-6. The suggestion that "Aymara" comes from the Aymara words "''jaya''" (ancient) and "''mara''" (year, time) is almost certainly a mistaken [[folk etymology]]. == Classification == It is often assumed that the Aymara language descends from the language spoken in [[Tiwanaku]] on the grounds that it is the native language of that area today. That is very far from certain, however, and most specialists now incline to the idea that Aymara did not expand into the Tiwanaku area until rather recently, as it spread southwards from an original homeland that was more likely to have been in Central Peru.{{cite book | last1 = Heggarty | first1 = P. | last2 = Beresford-Jones | first2 = D. | authorlink1 = |editor-first1=I. |editor-last1=Ness |editor-first2=Bellwood |editor-last2=P. |chapter= Andes: linguistic history. | title = The Encyclopedia of Global Human Migration | issue = | pages = 401–409 | year = 2013 |publisher= Wiley-Blackwell | location= Oxford }} Aymara placenames are found all the way north into central Peru. Indeed, (Altiplano) Aymara is actually the one of two extant members of a wider language family, the other surviving representative being [[Jaqaru language|Jaqaru]]. The family was established by the research of Lucy Briggs (a fluent speaker) and Dr. Martha Hardman de Bautista of the Program in Linguistics at the University of Florida. Jaqaru [''jaqi aru'' = human language] and Kawki communities are in the district of Tupe, Yauyos Valley, in the Dept. of Lima, in central Peru. Terminology for this wider language family is not yet well established. Hardman has proposed the name 'Jaqi' ('human') while other widely respected Peruvian linguists have proposed alternative names for the same language family. Alfredo Torero uses the term 'Aru' ('speech'); Rodolfo Cerrón-Palomino, meanwhile, has proposed that the term 'Aymara' should be used for the whole family, distinguished into two branches, Southern (or Altiplano) Aymara and Central Aymara (Jaqaru and Kawki). Each of these three proposals has its followers in Andean [[linguistics]]. In English usage, some linguists use the term [[Aymaran languages]] for the family and reserve 'Aymara' for the Altiplano branch. == Dialects == There is some degree of regional variation within Aymara, but all dialects are mutually intelligible.SIL's [http://www.ethnologue.com/ Ethnologue.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227170852/http://www.ethnologue.com/ |date=2007-12-27 }} and the ISO designate a [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=ayc Southern Aymara] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001211815/http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=ayc |date=2007-10-01 }} dialect found in between Lake Titicaca and the Pacific Coast in southern Peru and a [http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=ayr Central Aymara] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211054355/http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=ayr |date=2012-02-11 }} dialect found in western Bolivia and northeastern Chile. Such classifications, however, are not based upon academic research and are probably a misinterpretation of Cerrón-Palomino's classification of the language family.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Most studies of the language focused on either the Aymara spoken on the southern Peruvian shore of [[Lake Titicaca]] or the Aymara spoken around [[La Paz]]. Lucy Therina Briggs classifies both regions as being part of the Northern Aymara dialect, which encompasses the department of La Paz in Bolivia and the department of [[Puno]] in Peru. The Southern Aymara dialect is spoken in the eastern half of the [[Iquique]] province in northern Chile and in most of the Bolivian department of [[Oruro Department|Oruro]]. It is also found in northern [[Potosí]] and southwest [[Cochabamba]] but is slowly being replaced by Quechua in those regions. Intermediate Aymara shares dialectical features with both Northern and Southern Aymara and is found in the eastern half of the [[Tacna]] and [[Moquegua]] departments in southern Peru and in the northeastern tip of Chile.Lucy Therina Briggs, ''Dialectal Variation in the Aymara Language of Bolivia and Peru'', Dissertation, University of Florida, Gainesville, 1976; Adalberto Salas and María Teresa Poblete, "El aimara de Chile (fonología, textos, léxico)", ''Revista de Filología y Lingüística de la Universidad de Costa Rica'', Vol XXIII: 1, pp 121-203, 2, pp 95-138; Cerrón-Palomino, 2000, pp 65-8, 373. == Geographical distribution == [[File:Aymara-language-domain-en-001.svg|thumb|Aymara language domain as of 1984]] [[File:El aymara como lengua materna (censo nacional 2007).png|thumb|Distribution of Aymara limited to three southern departments in Peru: Puno, Moquegua, Tacna.]] There are roughly two million Bolivian speakers, half a million Peruvian speakers, and perhaps a few thousand speakers in Chile.Ethnologue: 1.785 million in Bolivia in 1987; 442 thousand of the central dialect in Peru in 2000, plus an unknown number of speakers of the southern dialect in Peru; 900 in Chile in 1994 out of a much larger ethnic population. At the time of the Spanish conquest in the sixteenth century, Aymara was the dominant language over a much larger area than today, including most of highland Peru south of [[Cusco]]. Over the centuries, Aymara has gradually lost speakers both to Spanish and to Quechua; many Peruvian and Bolivian communities that were once Aymara-speaking now speak Quechua.Xavier Albó, "Andean People in the Twentieth Century," in ''The Cambridge History of the Native Peoples of the Americas. Vol. III: South America'', ed. Frank Salomon and Stuart B. Schwartz (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1999), 765-871. == Phonology == === Vowels === Aymara has three [[phonemic]] [[vowel]]s {{IPA|/a i u/}}, which, in most varieties of the language, distinguish two degrees of length. Long vowels are indicated with a [[trema (diacritic)|diaeresis]] in writing: ''ä'', ''ï'', ''ü''. The high vowels are lowered to mid height when near uvular consonants ({{IPA|/i/}} → {{IPA|[e]}}, {{IPA|/u/}} → {{IPA|[o]}}). Vowel deletion is frequent in Aymara. Every instance of vowel deletion occurs for one of three reasons: (i) phonotactic, (ii) syntactic, and (iii) morphophonemic.Matt Coler, ''[http://www.brill.com/products/book/grammar-muylaq-aymara A Grammar of Muylaq' Aymara: Aymara as spoken in Southern Peru] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220041616/http://www.brill.com/products/book/grammar-muylaq-aymara |date=2014-12-20 }}''. Brill: Leiden, 2014. * Phonotactic vowel deletion, hiatus reduction, occurs when two vowels become adjacent as a consequence of word construction or through the process of suffixation. In such environments one of the two vowels deletes: (i) if one of the two vowels is {{IPA|/u/}}, that vowel will be the only one that surfaces, (ii) if the vowels are {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/a/}}, the {{IPA|/i/}} will surface. (iii) If the sequence is composed of two identical vowels, one will delete. * Vowel elision can be syntactically conditioned. For example, in nominal compounds and noun phrases, all adjectival/nominal modifiers with three or more vowels in a modifier + nucleus NP lose their final vowel. * Morphemic vowel deletion is the most common. Some suffixes always suppress the preceding vowel, and some lose their own nucleus under predictable conditions. The class of vowel-suppressing suffixes cannot be defined in terms of some common morphological, morpho-syntactic, or semantic feature. Suffixes from all categories in the language suppress the preceding vowel. === Consonants === As for the [[consonant]]s, Aymara has phonemic stops at the [[Labial consonant|labial]], [[Alveolar consonant|alveolar]], [[palatal]], [[velar]] and [[uvular]] points of articulation. Stops show no distinction of voice (e.g. there is no phonemic contrast between {{IPA|[p]}} and {{IPA|[b]}}), but each stop has three forms: plain ([[Tenuis consonant|tenuis]]), [[glottalization|glottalized]], and [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]]. Aymara also has a trilled {{IPA|/r/}}, and an alveolar/palatal contrast for nasals and laterals, as well as two semivowels ({{IPA|/w/}} and {{IPA|/j/}}). {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="2" | ! [[Lateral consonant|lateral]] | | {{IPAlink|l}} | | {{IPAlink|ʎ}} | | |- ! colspan="2" | [[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | {{IPAlink|r}} | | | | |} === Stress === Stress is usually on the second-to-last syllable, but long vowels may shift it. Although the final vowel of a word is elided except at the end of a phrase, the stress remains unchanged. === Syllable structure === The vast majority of roots are bisyllabic and, with few exceptions, [[suffix]]es are [[monosyllabic]]. Roots conform to the template (C)V(C)CV, with CVCV being predominant. The majority of suffixes are CV, though there are some exceptions: CVCV, CCV, CCVCV and even VCV are possible but rare. The agglutinative nature of this suffixal language, coupled with morphophonological alternations caused by vowel deletion and phonologically conditioned constraints, gives rise to interesting surface structures that operate in the domain of the morpheme, syllable, and phonological word/phrase. The phonological/morphophonological processes observed include syllabic reduction, epenthesis, deletion, and reduplication. == Orthography == [[File:Acta de Independencia de las Provincias Unidas en Sud América - Español - Aymara.jpg|thumb|250px|Declaration of Independence of the [[United Provinces of South America]] (present-day Argentina) in Spanish and Aymara]] Beginning with Spanish missionary efforts, there have been many attempts to create a writing system for Aymara. The colonial sources employed a variety of writing systems heavily influenced by Spanish, the most widespread one being that of [[Ludovico Bertonio|Bertonio]]. Many of the early grammars employed unique alphabets as well as the one of Middendorf's ''Aymara-Sprache'' (1891). The first official alphabet to be adopted for Aymara was the Scientific Alphabet. It was approved by the ''III Congreso Indigenista Interamericano de la Paz'' in 1954, though its origins can be traced as far back as 1931. Rs. No 1593 (Deza Galindo 1989, 17). It was the first official record of an alphabet, but in 1914, Sisko Chukiwanka Ayulo and Julián Palacios Ríos had recorded what may be the first of many attempts to have one alphabet for both Quechua and Aymara, the ''Syentifiko Qheshwa-Aymara Alfabeto'' with 37 graphemes.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Several other attempts followed, with varying degrees of success. Some orthographic attempts even expand further: the ''Alfabeto Funcional Trilingüe'', made up of 40 letters (including the voiced stops necessary for Spanish) and created by the Academia de las Lenguas Aymara y Quechua in Puno in 1944 is the one used by the lexicographer Juan Francisco Deza Galindo in his ''Diccionario Aymara – Castellano / Castellano – Aymara''.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} This alphabet has five vowels ⟨a, e, i, o, u⟩, aspiration is conveyed with an ⟨h⟩ next to the consonant, and ejectives with ⟨’⟩. The most unusual characteristic is the expression of the uvular /χ/ with ⟨jh⟩. The other uvular segment, /q/, is expressed by ⟨q⟩, but transcription rules mandate that the following vowel must be ⟨a, e, o⟩ (not ⟨i, u⟩), presumably to account for uvular lowering and to facilitate multilingual orthography. The alphabet created by the Comisión de Alfabetización y Literatura Aymara (CALA) was officially recognized in Bolivia in 1968 (co-existing with the 1954 Scientific Alphabet).{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Besides being the alphabet employed by Protestant missionaries, it is also the one used for the translation of the ''[[Book of Mormon]]''.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Also in 1968, de Dios Yapita created his take on the Aymara alphabet at the Instituto de Lenga y Cultura Aymara (ILCA).{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Nearly 15 years later, the ''Servicio Nacional de Alfabetización y Educación Popular'' (SENALEP) attempted to consolidate these alphabets to create a system which could be used to write both Aymara and Quechua, creating what was known as the Alfabeto Unificado. The alphabet, later sanctioned in Bolivia by Decree 20227 on 9 May 1984 and in Peru as la Resolución Ministerial Peruana 1218ED on 18 November 1985, consists of 3 vowels, 26 consonants and an [[umlaut (diacritic)|umlaut]] to mark vowel length.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} In this standard orthography, the consonants are represented as shown below. {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |- !colspan=2| ! [[Central consonant|central]] | | | | y | w | |- ! [[Lateral consonant|lateral]] | | l | | ll | | |- !colspan=2| [[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | r | | | | |} == Morphology == Aymara is a highly agglutinative, suffixal language. All suffixes can be categorized into the nominal, verbal, transpositional and those not subcategorized for lexical category (including stem-external word-level suffixes and phrase-final suffixes), as below: * Nominal and verbal morphology is characterized by derivational- and inflectional-like suffixes as well as non-productive suffixes. * Transpositional morphology consists of verbalizers (that operate on the root or phrasal levels) and nominalizers (including an action nominalizer, an agentive, and a resultative). * Suffixes not subcategorized for lexical category can be divided into three stem-external, word-level suffixes (otherwise known as "independent suffixes") and around a dozen phrase-final suffixes (otherwise known as "sentence suffixes"). === Nominal suffixes === * Non-productive nominal suffixes vary considerably by variant but typically include those below. Some varieties additionally also have (1) the suffix -''wurasa'' (< Spanish 'horas'), which expresses ‘when’ on ''aka'' ‘this’, ''uka'' ‘that’ and ''kuna'' ‘what’; (2) temporal suffixes -''unt'' ~ -''umt''; and (3) -''kucha'', which attaches to only two roots, ''jani'' ‘no’ and ''jicha'' ‘now’: ** kinship suffixes, including -''la'', -''lla'', -''chi'', and/or -''ta'' ** the expression of size with -''ch’a'' ** the suffix -''sa'' ‘side’, which attaches to only the demonstratives and ''kawki'' ‘where’ * Nominal derivational-like suffixes: ** diminutive suffixes ** delimitative suffix -''chapi'' * Nominal inflectional-like suffixes: ** Attributive suffix -''ni'' ** Possessive paradigm ** Plural -''naka'' ** Reciprocal/inclusor -''pacha'' ** Case suffixes - Syntactic relations are generally case-marked, with the exception of the unmarked subject. Case is affixed to the last element of a [[noun phrase]], usually corresponding to the head. Most varieties of Aymara have 14 cases (though in many, the genitive and locative have merged into a single form): [[ablative]] -''ta'', [[accusative]] (indicated by vowel suppression), [[allative]] -''ru'', [[benefactive]] -''taki'', [[comparative]] -''jama'', [[genitive]] -''na'', [[instrumental case|instrumental/comitative]] -''mpi'', interactive -''pura'', [[locative]] -''na'', limitative -''kama'', [[nominative case|nominative]] (zero), [[perlative case|perlative]] -''kata'', purposive -''layku''. === Verbal suffixes === All verbs require at least one suffix to be grammatical. * Verbal derivational-like suffixes ** Direction of motion — Although these suffixes are quite productive, they are not obligatory. The meaning of a word which is affixed with a member of this category is often but not always predictable, and the word formed may have a different meaning than the root. ** Spatial location — The nine spatial locations suffixes are likewise highly productive and not obligatory. Similarly, the meaning of the word that contains a member of this category is typically (but not consistently) predictable. There are also contexts in which the word formed has a meaning that significantly differs from that of the root to which it attaches. ** Valency-increasing — The five valency increasing suffixes may occur on a wide range of verbs but are not obligatory. The meaning expressed when a word receives one of these suffixes is predictable. ** Multipliers/reversers — The two multipliers/reversers are comparatively less productive and are not obligatory. In some contexts, attachment to a verb conveys a reverser meaning and effectively express the opposite of the meaning of the plain root. In this respect, the multipliers/reversers are the most derivational-like of all the suffixes discussed so far. ** Aspect — This category is complicated insofar as it is made up of a diverse array of suffix types, some of which are more productive and/or obligatory than others. ** Others — In some varieties of Aymara, there are three suffixes not classified into the categories above: the verbal comparative -''jama'', the category buffer -''(w)jwa'', and the intensifier -''paya''. Semantically, these three suffixes do not have much in common. They also vary with respect to the degree which they may be classified as more derivational-like or more inflectional-like. * Verbal inflectional-like suffixes: ** Person/tense — Person and tense are fused into a unitary suffix. These forms are among the most inflectional-like of the verbal suffixes insofar as they are all obligatory and productive. The so-called personal-knowledge tenses include the simple (non-past) and the proximal past. The non-personal knowledge tenses includes the future and distal past. ** Number — The plural verbal suffix, -''pha'' (just as the nominal one,-''naka'') is optional. Thus, while pluralization is very productive, it is not obligatory. ** Mood and modality — Mood and modality includes mood, evidentials, event modality, and the imperative. These suffixes are both productive and obligatory. Their semantic affect is usually transparent. === Transpositional suffixes === A given word can take several transpositional suffixes: * Verbalizers: There are six suffixes whose primary function is to verbalize nominal roots (not including the reflexive -''si'' and the propagative -''tata''). These forms can be subdivided into two groups, (1) phrase verbalizers and (2) root verbalizers. * Nominalizers: There are three suffixes are used to derive nouns: the agentive -''iri'', the resultative -''ta'', and the action nominalizer (sometimes glossed as the "infinitive" in some descriptions) -''ña''. === Suffixes not subcategorized for lexical categories === There are two kinds of suffixes not subcategorized for lexical categories: * Stem external word-final suffixes (sometimes known as "independent suffixes") — There are three suffixes that are not classifiable as members of either nominal or verbal morphology and are not phrase-final suffixes: the emphatic -''puni'', the delimitative -''ki'', and the additive -''raki'' * Phrase-final suffixes (sometimes known as "sentence suffixes" in the literature) — Most Aymara phrases have at least one of the eleven (depending on variant) possible phrase-final suffixes to be grammatical. The phrase-final suffix must appear minimally on a noun, noun phrase, verb, or verb phrase (note that two phrase-final suffixes, the additive -''sa'' and the confirmatory -''pi'' appear exclusively on nouns but otherwise pattern with phrase-final suffixes and so may not be best treated with nominal morphology). Exceptions to the requirement that a phrase has at least one phrase-final suffix are mainly limited to imperative constructions. == Idiosyncrasies == {{original research|date=October 2011}} Linguistic and gestural analysis by [[Rafael E. Núñez|Núñez]] and [[Eve Sweetser|Sweetser]] also asserts that the Aymara have an apparently-unique (or at least very rare) understanding of time. Aymara is, with Quechua, one of very few [Núñez & Sweetser, 2006, p. 403] languages in which speakers seem to represent the past as in front of them and the future as behind them. Their argument is mainly within the framework of [[conceptual metaphor]], which recognizes in general two subtypes of the metaphor "the passage of time is motion:" one is "time passing is motion over a landscape" (or "moving-ego"), and the other is "time passing is a moving object" ("moving-events"). The latter metaphor does not explicitly involve the individual/speaker. Events are in a queue, with prior events towards the front of the line. The individual may be facing the queue, or it may be moving from left to right in front of him/her. The claims regarding Aymara involve the moving-ego metaphor. Most languages conceptualize the ego as moving forward into the future, with ego's back to the past. The English sentences ''prepare for what lies before us'' and ''we are facing a prosperous future'' exemplify the metaphor. In contrast, Aymara seems to encode the past as in front of individuals and the future behind them. That is [[Linguistic typology|typologically]] a rare phenomenon [Núñez & Sweetser, 2006, p. 416]. The fact that English has words like ''before'' and ''after'' that are (currently or archaically) [[polysemy|polysemous]] between 'front/earlier' or 'back/later' may seem to refute the claims regarding Aymara uniqueness.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} However, those words relate events to other events and are part of the moving-events metaphor. In fact, when ''before'' means ''in front of '''ego''''', it can mean only ''future''. For instance, ''our future is laid out '''before us''''' while ''our past is '''behind us'''''. Parallel Aymara examples describe future days as ''qhipa uru'', literally 'back days', and they are sometimes accompanied by gestures to behind the speaker. The same applies to Quechua-speakers, whose expression ''qhipa p'unchaw'' corresponds directly to Aymara ''qhipa uru''. Possibly, the metaphor is from the fact that the past is visible (in front of one's eyes), but the future is not. == Pedagogy == There is increasing use of Aymara locally and there are increased numbers learning the language, both Bolivian and abroad. In Bolivia and Peru, [[intercultural bilingual education]] programs with Aymara and Spanish have been introduced in the last two decades. There are even projects to offer Aymara through the internet, such as by ILCA.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilcanet.org/ciberaymara|title=CIBERAYMARA|author=|date=|website=www.ilcanet.org|accessdate=8 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011132938/http://www.ilcanet.org/ciberaymara/|archivedate=11 October 2017|df=}} == See also == * [[Jaqaru language]] * [[Indigenous languages of the Americas]] * [[Languages of Peru]] * [[List of Spanish words of Indigenous American Indian origin]] == Notes == {{notelist}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == * Coler, Matt. {{refimprove|date=June 2017}} {{tone|date=June 2017}} The '''Cascade Center at the Riverplex''' is an indoor and outdoor shopping, dining, and entertainment complex located in downtown [[New Castle, Pennsylvania]]. It opened in 2006. Much of the complex sits on the former site of the Cascade, the first movie theater of the [[Warner Bros.]], hence the name. The complex is at the corner of East Washington Street and Mill Street. As of 2013, the complex is owned by Riverplex Partners, Inc. The top three stories are rented by Refresh Dental Management as their corporate headquarters.
==History== The [[Warner Bros.|Warners]], residents of nearby [[Youngstown, Ohio]], were sons of [[Polish Jew]]s wanting to break into the then-fledgling film business. The brothers, after successfully showing a used copy of ''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'' at ''[[Idora Park, Youngstown|Idora Park]]'' in Youngstown,<ref>Warner (1964), pp. 49–54.</ref> traveled to New Castle to screen the movie in a vacant store on the site of what would become the Cascade Center.<ref name="Warner54-55">Warner and Jennings (1964), pp. 54–55.</ref> This makeshift theatre, called the Bijou, was furnished with chairs borrowed from a local undertaker.<ref name="ohiomag-march83">{{cite news | first = Bob | last = Trebilcock | title = A Warner Brothers Production: They parlayed Youngstown nickelodeon into a Hollywood empire | work = Ohio Magazine | date = March 1985 | pages = 24–25 }}</ref><ref name="variety-09-13-78"> {{cite news | title = Jack L. Warner's Death Closes Out Pioneer Clan of 'Talkies' | work = Variety | date = September 13, 1978 | page = 2 }}</ref> In 1906, the brothers purchased a small theater in New Castle near the Bijou, which they called the Cascade Movie Palace, taking its name from nearby [[Cascade Park (amusement park)|Cascade Park]]. They maintained the theater until moving into film distribution in 1907.
Gradually over time, the building that housed the Bijou would host other business while the Cascade itself would eventually be demolished to make way for a [[parking lot]]. The buildings themselves would become abandoned by the 1980s when New Castle, like most other [[Rust Belt]] cities, saw the collapse of the [[steel]] industry having a ripple effect in the region with the population dropping as well as the general [[suburbanization]] effect that had been happening throughout the [[United States]] since the 1950s.
By the mid-1990s, only two businesses were open on the site that would become the Cascade Center. One of them, Main Street Clothiers & Custom Tailors, is a men's [[Suit (clothing)|suit]] shop that was housed in the building that also housed the Bijou. The other would be the [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad|B&O Railroad]] Federal Credit Union, a [[credit union]] that was in a separate purpose-built building on the site bordering Mill Street and the [[Neshannock Creek]] and had actually been built on the site of the Cascade after the site was used as a parking lot.
In 1996, parts of the wall of the building that housed the Bijou collapsed onto East Washington Street, one of the cities main thoroughfares. The portion that collapsed was next door to Main Street Clothiers, which had just opened three years before on the site. The city of New Castle was very close to issuing a [[Occupancy|condemnation]] notice to the building, but at the 11th hour the building's historical significance was discovered, saving the building. The city then announced redevelopment plans to make it what would eventually become the Cascade Center.
==Development== The city took most of the property by [[eminent domain]] and stabilized the parts of the wall that had collapsed, closing off the [[sidewalk]] in front of the building to prevent accidents until the wall could be completely rebuilt. The city was later able to persuade the B&O Credit Union—now the First Choice Federal Credit Union—to temporarily move into the nearby mall, the Cascade Galleria, so that the property could be bought and made into the Cascade Center. (The credit union eventually moved out of the mall back into their own building out in neighboring [[Union Township, Lawrence County, Pennsylvania|Union Township]].) Main Street Clothiers was allowed to stay in the building where they remain today, and although their portion of the building is not officially part of the Cascade Center they do advertise in the complex, and have even expanded their business by [[screen-printing]] [[T-shirt]]s as well as serving as the area's [[J. C. Penney]] Catalog Center after [[Rite Aid]] acquired [[Eckerd Corporation|Eckerd Pharmacy]] in 2007 and ended the J. C. Penney Catalog Center's in the former Eckerd locations after they were converted to Rite Aid. Coincidentally, Main Street sits next door to a former J. C. Penney (not the side that had the wall collapse) that is currently being remodeled and eventually having a [[coffeehouse|coffee shop]] open in the building.
Although the downtown streets & sidewalks were rebuilt in the early 2000s to resemble the turn of the 19th century, the complex itself wouldn't begin reconstruction until 2003 and was completed in 2006. The interiors of the existing buildings were completely gutted out while the site of the Cascade itself was completely rebuilt into a close replication of the Cascade. Both the old sections and the newly built sections are like one building inside. The city was also able to acquire the former [[Mellon Financial|Mellon Bank]] parking lot and rebuild it as the parking lot for downtown in general and the Cascade Center specifically. The [[alley]] that ran along Neshannock Creek behind the buildings was permanently closed and added on to the property of the complex, which became a [[Esplanade|promenade]] that leads to an outdoor [[Amphitheatre|amphitheater]] between the former J. C. Penney building and the creek along East Washington Street. The northern terminus of [[Pennsylvania Route 65]] (which runs along East Washington Street) was extended over a mile to near the complex on the other side of the creek.
Much like [[Station Square]] in [[Pittsburgh]], the complex is an example of [[adaptive reuse]], and focuses on the early years of [[Film|motion pictures]] much like Station Square focuses on [[train]]s. The complex largely remains vacant, although businesses have started to open up and events being held both inside the complex and at the amphitheater. The complex has also help draw businesses to downtown.
Despite the historical connection to the Warner Bros. studio, the complex has no association with [[Time Warner]], the current parent company of Warner Bros. Entertainment. Cass Warner, the granddaughter of [[Harry Warner]], did visit the complex just before it officially opened in 2006.<ref>http://www.ncnewsonline.com/archivesearch/local_story_112013504?start:int=30{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Tenants== Although at one point the complex had three tenants, in 2010 all three closed for unknown reasons and the complex was put up for sale. The outdoor promenade and amphitheater, which are publicly owned, are still used by the city for downtown events.
It should also be noted that Main Street Clothiers and Custom Tailors, while in the building where the Cascade Center is located, is not an official part of the complex, since it has outdoor access only instead of indoor access like the rest of the businesses and also was pre-existing before the creation of the complex.
Reinvestment in the center has picked up in recent years, with the Two Rivers Coffee Shop and The Commonwealth restaurant both opening in 2014.

དབུས་གཙང་སྐད་ ''Dbus-gtsang skad / Ü-tsang kä'' |pronunciation={{IPA-bo|wýkɛʔ, wýʔtsáŋ kɛʔ|}} |states=China ([[Tibet Autonomous Region]]), [[Nepal]], India |region = |speakers={{sigfig|1.172940|2}} million |date=1990 census |ref = e18 |script=[[Tibetan script]] |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam2=[[Tibeto-Burman]] |fam3=[[Tibeto-Kanauri languages|Tibeto-Kanauri]] ? |fam4=[[Bodish languages|Bodish]] |fam5=[[Tibetic languages|Tibetic]] |stand1=[[Standard Tibetan]] |lc1=bod|ld1=[[Lhasa Tibetan]] |lc2=dre|ld2=Dolpo |lc3=hut|ld3=Humla, Limi |lc4=lhm|ld4=Lhomi (Shing Saapa) |lc5=muk|ld5=[[Mugom dialect|Mugom]] (Mugu) |lc6=kte|ld6=Nubri |lc8=ola|ld8=Walungge (Gola) |lc9=loy|ld9=Lowa/Loke (Mustang) |lc10=tcn|ld10=Tichurong |lc11=thw|ld11=Thudam (duplicate code) |glotto=tibe1272 |glottoname=Tibetan |glotto2=sout3216 |glottoname2=South-Western Tibetic (partial match) |glottorefname2=South-Western Tibetic |glotto3=basu1243 |glottoname3=Basum }} '''Central Tibetan''', also known as '''Dbus''', '''Ü''' or '''Ü-Tsang''', is the most widely spoken [[Tibetic languages|Tibetic language]] and the basis of [[Standard Tibetan]]. ''Dbus'' and ''Ü'' are forms of the same name. ''Dbus'' is a transliteration of the name in [[Tibetan script]], {{lang|bo|དབུས་}}, whereas ''Ü'' is the pronunciation of the same in Lhasa dialect, {{IPA-bo|wy˧˥˧ʔ|}} (or {{IPA|[y˧˥˧ʔ]}}). That is, in Tibetan, the name is spelled ''Dbus'' and pronounced ''Ü''. All of these names are frequently applied specifically to the [[prestige dialect]] of Lhasa. There are many [[mutually intelligible]] Central Tibetan dialects besides that of Lhasa, with particular diversity along the border and in Nepal:N. Tournadre (2005) "L'aire linguistique tibétaine et ses divers dialectes." ''Lalies'', 2005, n°25, p. 7–56 [http://www.nicolas-tournadre.net/wp-content/uploads/multimedia/2005-aire.pdf] :[[Limi]] (Limirong), [[Mugom dialect|Mugum]], [[Dolpo]] (Dolkha), [[Mustang (kingdom)|Mustang]] (Lowa, Lokä), [[Humla]], Nubri, Lhomi, Dhrogpai Gola, [[Walungchung Gola]] (Walungge/Halungge), [[Tseku language|Tseku]], [[Basum language|Basum]] ''Ethnologue'' reports that Walungge is highly intelligible with Thudam, ''Glottolog'' that Thudam is not a distinct variety. Tournadre (2013) classifies Tseku with [[Khams Tibetan|Khams]]. ==See also== *[[Amdo Tibetan]] *[[Ladakhi language]] *[[Balti language]] *[[Ü-Tsang]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{interwiki|code=bo|Central Tibetan}} {{Languages of China}} {{Bodic languages}} [[Category:Languages of China]] [[Category:Languages of Nepal]] [[Category:Central Bodish languages]] [[Category:Languages of Tibet]] [[Category:Languages written in Tibetan script]] {{st-lang-stub}}

The '''Climate Summit 2014''' (sometimes also referred to as the '''Leader's Climate Summit''') was a meeting on climate change in [[New York City|New York]] on September 23, 2014. UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] announced it in September 2013 and invited leaders of governments, the private sector, and civil society to unite in taking concrete action towards a low-carbon world.
The Summit's focus was on initiatives and actions rather than on negotiations between countries. It was seen as a milestone on the path towards closing the ''emissions gap'' between reduction pledges and the necessary emission cuts for the [[Climate change mitigation|2 °C scenario]] (with "pursue efforts to" limit the temperature increase to 1.5 °C), and to a new legal agreement on climate change, to be approved by the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP21 in Paris]] in December 2015. One product of the Summit was the [[New York Declaration on Forests]].
== Developments and positions prior to the Summit == After the [[2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP19 in Warsaw]], the Climate Summit was the next high-level gathering on climate change. Since the [[Kyoto Protocol]]'s second commitment period expires in 2020, the [[UNFCCC]] process attempts to establish a new worldwide contract about climate protection and emission reduction objectives, that is to be drafted in 2014 at the [[2014 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP20 in Lima]] and adopted in 2015 at the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP21 in Paris]]. The Climate Summit in September 2014 is not part of this negotiating process, but is expected to serve as a kick-off for a year of intense activity in climate policy and an indicator on the countries' ambitions to reduce emissions and support climate protection. Having this in mind, UN Secretary-General Ban invited leaders of governments, the private sector and [[civil society]] from all over the world to unite in action:
{{quote|I challenge you to bring to the Summit bold pledges. Innovate, scale-up, cooperate and deliver concrete action that will close the emissions gap and put us on track for an ambitious legal agreement through the UNFCCC process.|UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon<ref>[https://www.un.org/climatechange/summit2014 ''Climate Summit 2014''], un.org; visited March 26, 2014.</ref>}}
In December 2013, Secretary-General Ban appointed the former President of Ghana, [[John Kufuor]], and [[Jens Stoltenberg]], former Prime Minister of Norway, as special envoys on climate change, to assist Ban in connection with the Climate Summit and provide strategic advice.<ref>[http://summit.sites.unicnetwork.org/2013/12/23/secretary-general-appoints-special-envoys-on-climate-change-to-engage-global-leaders-ahead-of-2014-climate-summit/#more-113 ''Secretary-General appoints special envoys on climate change''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416175308/http://summit.sites.unicnetwork.org/2013/12/23/secretary-general-appoints-special-envoys-on-climate-change-to-engage-global-leaders-ahead-of-2014-climate-summit/#more-113#more-113 |date=2014-04-16 }}, unicnetwork.org; visited March 19, 2014.</ref>
In preparation of the Climate Summit, on May 4 and 5 the ''Abu Dhabi Ascent'' was held in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[UAE]], as a meeting in order to cross-link initiatives between governments, the private sector and civil society and to "generate momentum" for the Climate Summit.<ref>[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=47073 ''United Arab Emirates to host meeting ahead of UN chief’s climate summit''], un.org; visited March 25, 2014.</ref>
In July 2014, Ban Ki-moon appointed former [[President of Ireland]], and former [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]], [[Mary Robinson]], a special envoy for climate change to interact with global leaders ahead of the Climate Summit, to forge political commitment towards finalizing an agreement in 2015.<ref name="ClimateChange">{{cite news|title=Robinson to head United Nations effort on climate change|url=http://www.irishsun.com/index.php/sid/223797021/scat/aba4168066a10b8d/ht/Robinson-to-head-United-Nations-effort-on-climate-change|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=''Irish Sun.com''|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715110732/http://www.irishsun.com/index.php/sid/223797021/scat/aba4168066a10b8d/ht/Robinson-to-head-United-Nations-effort-on-climate-change|archive-date=2014-07-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Location and participation == [[File:20140921 xl mal-schnell-die-welt-retten-avaaz-demo 9375.JPG|thumb|''mal-schnell-die-welt-retten'', Climate March in Berlin (21 September 2014)]] The Climate Summit took place at [[UN Headquarters]] in [[New York City]] on September 23, 2014, one day ahead of the annual [[UN General Assembly|General Assembly Debate]].
A [[People's Climate March|major protest against climate change]] took place outside the conference and on Sunday two days before the conference in other countries worldwide to encourage the leaders to take strong climate action.

[[File:15_10_01_CISTEM_Training_CIC.png|thumb|Students with disabilities taking CISTEM courses at the United States Embassy in Lome, Togo in October of 2015.]] People with '''disabilities in Togo''' face many unique challenges. Disability in [[Togo]] is often seen as a [[curse]] or sign of [[witchcraft]], leading to poor outcomes for people with disabilities. [[Accessibility]] in the country is lacking. However, Togo has signed onto the UN [[Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities]] and has created plans to encourage greater inclusion for people with disabilities in the country.
== Demographics == [[Census]] data from 2010 shows that approximately 1.36% of the population of Togo has a disability of some type.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://togo.opendataforafrica.org/xurbfzd/population-with-disabilities|title=Population With Disabilities - Portail de données du Togo|last=Cheryshev|first=Denis|date=26 May 2015|work=Knoema|access-date=2018-07-29|language=}}</ref> Like many other countries in Africa, children in Togo often become disabled due to various complications, disease, poor diet and other causes.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/togo/relieving-disabled-children-crippling-customs|title=Relieving disabled children from crippling customs|last=|first=|date=19 June 2012|work=ReliefWeb|access-date=2018-07-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180729212154/https://reliefweb.int/report/togo/relieving-disabled-children-crippling-customs|archive-date=29 July 2018|language=en}}</ref>
== Cultural attitudes towards disability == Children who are born with a disability in [[Togo]], like in some other [[West Africa|West African]] countries, can face violence at home, school or from other members of the community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nyu.edu/content/nyu/en/about/news-publications/news/2018/february/children-with-disabilities-in-west-africa-experience-violence-fr|title=Children with Disabilities in West Africa Experience Violence from the Day they are Born|last=|first=|date=1 February 2018|website=NYU|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref> Disability is seen as a sign of [[witchcraft]] and is considered [[taboo]] by some communities.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://thisisafrica.me/togo-disabled-childrens-labeled-witchcraft-prisoners/|title=Togo where disabled children’s accused of witchcraft are imprisoned and ostracised|last=Obera|first=Fred|date=2017-05-16|work=This Is Africa|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en-US}}</ref> Other times, the disability is considered the "result of a [[demon]] in the family."<ref name=":2" /> Children with disabilities might also face [[neglect]] at home.{{Sfn|Njelesani|Hashemi|Cameron|Cameron|2018|p=4}} Children born with a physical disability are viewed as "a non-human spirit," by some families.{{Sfn|Njelesani|Hashemi|Cameron|Cameron|2018|p=5}} Some parents deliberately keep their children out of school to protect them from abuse there.{{Sfn|Njelesani|Hashemi|Cameron|Cameron|2018|p=5}} People with disabilities in Togo in general were considered [[Curse|cursed]] and that the disability could be [[Contagious disease|contagious]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/togo-sees-progress-struggle-rights-people-disabilities|title=Togo sees progress in the struggle for the rights of people with disabilities|last=Abi|first=Samir|date=26 July 2014|work=D+C|access-date=2018-07-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503134631/http://www.dandc.eu/en/article/togo-sees-progress-struggle-rights-people-disabilities|archive-date=3 May 2015|language=en}}</ref> Violence against children with disabilities and their deaths often goes unreported to authorities.<ref name=":3" /> Often entire families are [[Ostracism|ostracized]] because of one family members' disability.<ref name=":2" />
People with [[Mental disorder|mental disabilities]] in Togo may be chained up in places known as [[prayer camps]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/12/health/the-chains-of-mental-illness-in-west-africa.html|title=The Chains of Mental Illness in West Africa|last=Carey|first=Benedict|date=11 October 2015|work=New York Times|access-date=2018-07-29|language=en}}</ref> These camps are religious institutions where individuals are restrained, not given [[Psychiatry|psychiatric]] help and are [[Prayer|prayed over]] in an attempt to heal the individuals.<ref name=":1" /> In Togo, there are several prayer camps which use different methods, often based on the camp's head [[Pastor|pastors]]' personality.<ref name=":1" />
== Policy == There is a lack of inclusion for people with disabilities in leadership positions in Togo.<ref name=":0" /> In 2013, [[Jérémie Yao Vidja]], who is [[Visual impairment|visually impaired]], became the first person with a disability to run for elected office in Togo and he was later elected to the [[National Assembly (Togo)|Togolese National Assembly]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://visionssolidaires.com/2013/08/07/revue-de-presse-jeremie-yao-vidja-premier-malvoyant-depute-au-togo/|title=Revue de presse: Jérémie Yao Vidja, premier malvoyant député au Togo|date=2013-08-07|work=Visions Solidaires|access-date=2018-07-29|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
The [[Politics of Togo|government in Togo]] signed on to the [[Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities|UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities]] in 2011.<ref name=":2" /> In 2016, Togo's [[Ministry of Social Action]] created a committee dedicated to "fostering social inclusion for people with disabilities."{{Sfn|ICRC|2017|p=3}} In 2017, [[Universal health care|Universal Health Coverage]] was given to all students living in Togo.{{Sfn|ICRC|2017|p=1}}
=== Infrastructure === Togo's public buildings are still not fully accommodating to people with physical disabilities.<ref name=":0" /> In addition, there is no legislation requiring [[accessibility]] in public areas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.countryreports.org/travel/Togo/accessibility.htm|title=Disability Access In Togo|last=|first=|date=|website=Country Reports|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=29 July 2018}}</ref>
=== Education === [[File:15_10_01_CISTEM_Training_CIC2.png|thumb|Students with disabilities taking CISTEM courses at the United States Embassy in Lome, Togo in October of 2015.]] People with disabilities were first allowed to attend public schools in the 1970s.<ref name=":0" /> Also in the 1970s, [[Germany|German]] and [[United States|American]] charities set up special-needs schools, focusing on students with visual impairment.<ref name=":0" /> By 2014, there were nine schools and centers for children with intellectual disabilities, with most located in [[Lomé]].<ref name=":0" /> Also by 2014, schools for those with hearing impairment had been created.<ref name=":0" />
Efforts at including students with disabilities has started to increase. In 2014, there were hundreds of students with various physical disabilities were enrolled in universities around Togo, including 27 visually impaired students at the [[University of Lomé]].<ref name=":0" />
=== Non governmental organizations === [[Non-governmental organization|Non governmental organizations]] recognize that they need to work closely with the [[Ministry of Health (Togo)|Ministry of Health]] and the [[Ministry of Education (Togo)|Ministry of Education]] in Togo.<ref name=":2" /> [[Handicap International|Humanity & Inclusion]] (HI), started a trial program in Togo and other African countries to help produce [[3D printing|3D-printed]] [[Prosthesis|prosthetic]] limbs for [[Amputation|amputees]] in need.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/3d-printing-trial-launched-to-help-amputees-in-madagascar-togo/|title=3D printing trial launched to help amputees in Madagascar, Togo|last=Osborne|first=Charlie|date=9 July 2018|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-07-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180729185217/https://www.zdnet.com/article/3d-printing-trial-launched-to-help-amputees-in-madagascar-togo/|archive-date=29 July 2018|language=en}}</ref>
== Disability culture ==
=== Sports === Participating in sports among people with disabilities is increasing, with hundreds participating in various trials in 2013 leading up to the pan-African competitions.<ref name=":0" /> Togo sent a [[Paralympic Games|Paralympic]] athlete, [[Aliou Bawa]], to the [[Togo at the 2016 Summer Paralympics|2016 Summer Paralympics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.togonews.info/pages/posts/en-preparation-pour-rio-aliou-bawa-vient-de-battre-son-record-de-brazzaville-en-soulevant-un-poids-de-plus-de-125-kg-985.php?p=50|title=En préparation pour Rio, Aliou Bawa vient de battre son record de Brazzaville en soulevant un poids de plus de 125 kg|last=|first=|date=|website=Togo News|language=French|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227035642/http://www.togonews.info/pages/posts/en-preparation-pour-rio-aliou-bawa-vient-de-battre-son-record-de-brazzaville-en-soulevant-un-poids-de-plus-de-125-kg-985.php?p=50|archive-date=27 February 2018|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref>
== References ==
=== Citations === {{Reflist|30em}}
=== Sources ===
*{{Cite book|url=http://moveability.icrc.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/111/2017/12/Togo_factsheet.pdf|title=Disability Rehabilitation Inclusion - Togo|last=ICRC|first=|publisher=MoveAbility|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=|ref=harv|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180729213348/http://moveability.icrc.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/111/2017/12/Togo_factsheet.pdf|archive-date=29 July 2018}} *{{Cite journal|last=Njelesani|first=Janet|last2=Hashemi|first2=Goli|last3=Cameron|first3=Cathy|last4=Cameron|first4=Deb|last5=Richard|first5=Danielle|last6=Parnes|first6=Penny|date=17 January 2018|title=From the Day they Are Born: A Qualitative Study Exploring Violence Against Children With Disabilities in West Africa|url=https://www.dropbox.com/s/p58j0xefu8b016i/Njelesani%20J.%20-%20BMC%20Public%20Health%20-%20Violence%20Against%20Children%20with%20Disabilities%20in%20West%20Africa.pdf?dl=0|journal=BMC Public Health|volume=18|pages=1-7|doi=10.1186/s12889-018-5057-x|ref=harv|via=}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox organization | name = The European Union Anti-Corruption Initiative | logo = EUACI.jpg | motto = | type = | founded_date = {{Start date|2017}} | founder = | origins = [[Kyiv]], Ukraine | key_people = [[Eka Tkeshelashvili]] | area_served = Ukraine | focus = Counteraction of [[Corruption in Ukraine]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | homepage = {{URL|euaci.eu/|www.euaci.eu}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''European Union Anti-Corruption Initiative''', EUACI, is the largest program<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kmu.gov.ua/ua/news/250049373 |title=Launch the new EU Anti-Corruption Initiative |author= |date=2 June 2017 |website= |publisher=Government of Ukraine |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> of technical assistance in fighting [[corruption in Ukraine|corruption]] implemented by the [[European Union]] in [[Ukraine]].
The program was established in June 2017 and it is expected that it will run for three years (2017–2019). It is mainly funded by the [[European Commission]] and co-funded by [[Danish International Development Agency]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.unian.info/politics/1977569-eu-officials-support-establishment-of-anticorruption-court-in-ukraine.html |title=EU officials support establishment of anticorruption court in Ukraine |author= |date=15 June 2017 |website= |publisher=UNIAN news. The latest news in Ukraine and worldwide |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806053027/https://www.unian.info/politics/1977569-eu-officials-support-establishment-of-anticorruption-court-in-ukraine.html |archive-date=2017-08-06 |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref>
== Mission and Aims == {{See also|Corruption in Ukraine}} EUACI in Ukraine was created with the aim of strengthening the capability of the anti-corruption institutions and increasing parliamentary, civic society and media control over the reforms in Ukraine.<ref name=abouteuaci>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/who-we-are/about-programme |title=About Programme |author= |date= |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 |quote=}}</ref><ref name=openaid>{{cite web |url=http://openaid.gov.ua/en/projects/7414 |title=EU Anti-Corruption Initiative in Ukraine |author= |date=15 March 2017 |website= |publisher=Open Aid Ukraine |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 }}</ref>
The aims of the program are as follows:<ref name=nazkcard>{{cite web |url=https://nazk.gov.ua/sites/default/files/docs/2017/міжнародні%20програми/EUACI.pdf |title=Реєстраційна картка проекту (програми) №3582-01 |author= |date=5 April 2017 |website= |publisher=National agency on corruption prevention |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=Registration card of the project (program) No. 3582-01 }}</ref> * improvement of anti-corruption politics implementation * facilitation of reduction in large scale corruption * strengthening of operational and legislative potential of state institutions in prevention and elimination of corruption * increase of parliamentary supervision of reforms, and potential of studying and improving the strategic legislative basis * increase of the potential of local governments, public and media which would enable them to contribute towards anti-corruption activities
== Funding == The overall budget of the program is 15.84 million euros. The immediate executor of the program representing the [[Kingdom of Denmark]] is [[DANIDA]].<ref name=abouteuaci/><ref name=interfax>{{cite web |url=https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/425691.html |title= EU's three-year anti-corruption initiative launched in Ukraine |author= |date=1 June 2017 |website= |publisher=Interfax-Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601184544/https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/425691.html |archive-date=2017-06-01 |access-date=2018-05-13 |quote=}}</ref> The project is implemented as international technical aid, according to Contract No 3582–01 from 15 March 2017,<ref name=openaid/> under the Framework Agreement between Ukraine and [[European Commission]] (ratified together with the notice under the Law 360–VI (360–17) from 3 September 2008).<ref name=nazkcard/> It became the first large scale project aimed at fighting corruption.<ref name=abouteuaci/><ref name=interfax/>
== Implementation == The program is expected to be implemented during over a period of 3 years, between 15 December 2016 – 14 December 2019.<ref name=openaid/> It comprises three сomponents: # Supporting of state agencies dealing with the prevention and fight against corruption. # The assistance to Ukrainian parliament implementation of anti-corruption reforms. # The assistance for local government, civil society, and media of anti-corruption activities (integrity cities, civil society organisations, investigative journalists).<ref name=abouteuaci/><ref name>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/what-we-do/components/ |title=Components |author= |date= |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 |quote=}}</ref>
== Activities of the EUACI == === Component 1 === EUACI provides consultative, organisational and financial assistance to the special anti-corruption institutions.
Implemented projects: * IT equipment for The Asset Recovery and Management Agency of Ukraine<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.unian.info/society/2248789-euaci-transfers-uah-2-mln-worth-of-it-equipment-to-arma.html |title=EUACI transfers UAH 2 mln worth of IT equipment to ARMA |author= |date=17 November 2017 |website= |publisher=UNIAN news. The latest news in Ukraine and worldwide |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117170248/https://www.unian.info/society/2248789-euaci-transfers-uah-2-mln-worth-of-it-equipment-to-arma.html |archive-date=2017-11-17 |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> * Technical support for the Regional Press Development Institute<ref>{{cite web |url=https://irrp.org.ua/vykorystannya-mizhnarodnoyi-tehnichnoyi-dopomogy/ |title=Використання міжнародної технічної допомоги |author=Осока Сергій |date=25 May 2017 |website= |publisher=Regional press development institute |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201204403/https://irrp.org.ua/vykorystannya-mizhnarodnoyi-tehnichnoyi-dopomogy/ |archive-date=2017-12-01 |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=Use of international technical assistance |quote=}}</ref> * Analysis of the business processes used for the electronic tax declarations :This analysis includes identification of problems and development of measures allowing to make necessary improvements in the business processes used for the tax declaration evaluation. The project was delivered together with the [[National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine]] (in October 2017).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nazk.gov.ua/news/v-nazk-prezentovano-zvit-z-rezultatamy-analizu-biznes-procesiv-povnoyi-perevirky-e-deklaraciy |title=В НАЗК презентовано звіт з результатами аналізу бізнес-процесів повної перевірки е-декларацій |author= |date=5 October 2017 |website= |publisher=National agency on corruption prevention |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171006134531/https://nazk.gov.ua/news/v-nazk-prezentovano-zvit-z-rezultatamy-analizu-biznes-procesiv-povnoyi-perevirky-e-deklaraciy |archive-date=2017-10-06 |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=NACP presented a report with the results of the analysis of business processes, full verification of e-declarations }}</ref> * Creation of a learning working group led by Eric Heldna (the length of the this project was half a year)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/469925.html |title= Former Estonian police official to tackle corruption in Ukraine |author= |date=14 December 2017 |website= |publisher=Interfax-Ukraine |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171214132730/https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/469925.html |archive-date=2017-12-14 |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://hromadske.ua/posts/yak-trenuyut-ahentiv-nabu |title=Тренер НАБУ: Розкриття агента може коштувати комусь життя |author=Дмитро Реплянчук |date=26 January 2018 |website= |publisher=Hromadske International |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128055113/https://hromadske.ua/posts/yak-trenuyut-ahentiv-nabu |archive-date=2018-01-28 |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=NABU Coach: Agent disclosure can cost someone's life }}</ref> * Assistance in typological research allowing to discover new trends and schemes in money laundering and financing of terrorism (the project was carried out by the State Financial Monitoring Service of Ukraine)<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.kmu.gov.ua/ua/news/derzhfinmonitoring-za-pidtrimki-antikorupcijnoyi-iniciativi-yevropejskogo-soyuzu-euaci-vidav-zbirku-tipologichnih-doslidzhen |title=Держфінмоніторинг за підтримки Антикорупційної Ініціативи Європейського Союзу (EUACI) видав Збірку типологічних досліджень |author= |date=20 April 2018 |website= |publisher=Government of Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180420153355/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/ua/news/derzhfinmonitoring-za-pidtrimki-antikorupcijnoyi-iniciativi-yevropejskogo-soyuzu-euaci-vidav-zbirku-tipologichnih-doslidzhen |archive-date=2018-04-20 |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=SFMSU with the support of the EU Anti-Corruption Initiative (EUACI) issued the Collection of Typological Studies }}</ref> * A learning visit to [[Lithuania]] for the [[Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office|SAPO]] and [[National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine|NABU]] employees (28–29 August 2017)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.urm.lt/default/en/news/lithuania-strongly-supports-ukraines-efforts-to-tackle-corruption |title=Lithuania strongly supports Ukraine's efforts to tackle corruption |author= |date=28 August 2017 |website= |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/445014.html |title= Lithuania supports soonest creation of anti-corruption court in Ukraine |author= |date= |website= |publisher=Interfax-Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829175719/https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/445014.html |archive-date=2017-08-29 |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> * A visit of the NABU delegation to the [[Eurojust]] in the [[Hague]], [[Netherlands]] (14–15 March 2018)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/news/pravozaxisni-institucziji-jevropejskogo-soyuzu-v-gaazi-podililisya-dosvidom-z-ukrajinskimi-kolegami |title=Law enforcement experts share their experience with Ukrainian counterparts in The Hague |author= |date=17 March 2018 |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://nabu.gov.ua/en/novyny/nabu-employees-will-strengthen-cooperation-europol-and-eurojust |title=NABU employees will strengthen cooperation with Europol and Eurojust |author= |date=16 March 2018 |website= |publisher=[[National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine]] |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rbc.ua/ukr/news/nabu-usilivaet-sotrudnichestvo-evropolom-1521215820.html |title=НАБУ посилює співпрацю з Європолом та Євроюстом |author= |date=16 March 2018 |website= |publisher=RBC–Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316185809/https://www.rbc.ua/ukr/news/nabu-usilivaet-sotrudnichestvo-evropolom-1521215820.html |archive-date=2018-03-16 |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=NABU strengthens cooperation with Europol and Eurojust }}</ref> * NABU professionals attended studies in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]] (19–21 March 2018).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/news/litovski-pravooxoronczi-podililisya-dosvidom-z-ukrajinskimi-analitikami-ta-detektivami-nabu |title= NABU study tour to Lithuania |author= |date=21 March 2018 |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref>
=== Component 2 === Implemented projects: * Creation of International Anti-Corruption Advisory Board (IACAB) The IACAB was created on 8 September 2017 as a result of the a Letter of Intent being signed between the [[Verkhovna Rada]] Anti-Corruption Committee and EUACI.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.um.dk/en/About-us/news/newsdisplaypage/?newsID=46BB089D-EF5D-47B0-8E82-9BBBE38158CE |title=First meeting of the EUACI International Anti-Corruption Board 6–8 September |author= |date=5 September 2017 |website= |publisher=Denmark in Ukraine: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://rada.gov.ua/fsview/148290.html |title=Підписано Меморандум про наміри між Комітетом з питань запобігання і протидії корупції та Програмою "Антикорупційна ініціатива Європейського Союзу в Україні" (EUACI) (документ) |author=Information department of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine |date=8 September 2017 |website= |publisher=Official portal of [[Verkhovna Rada|the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]] |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13 |language=uk |trans-title=Memorandum of Intent between the Committee for the Prevention and Counteraction of Corruption and the Program EUACI is signed (document) }}</ref>
It consists of the following members: [[Carlos Castresana]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://voxukraine.org/en/item/carlos-castresana/ |title=Carlos Castresana |author= |date= |website= |publisher=VoxUkraine |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> [[Anca Jurma]], [[Giovanni Kessler]], [[Drago Kos]], [[Jesper Hjortenberg]], [[Daniel Thelesklaf]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.um.dk/~/media/Ukraine/Documents/News/2017/International%20Anti-Corruption%20Board%20Short%20Biographical%20Notes.pdf |title= Short Biographical Notes: International Anti-Corruption Advisory Board Members |author= |date=5 September 2017 |website= |publisher=Denmark in Ukraine: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://crimecor.rada.gov.ua/news/anons_pd/73593.html |title=Про візит делегації Антикорупційної ініціативи ЄС в Україні (EUACI) та Міжнародної антикорупційної консультативної ради (IACAB) |author= |date=13 April 2018 |website= |publisher=Verkhovna Rada Anti-Corruption Committee |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180420202956/http://crimecor.rada.gov.ua/news/anons_pd/73593.html |archive-date=2018-04-20 |access-date=2018-06-13 |language=uk |trans-title=About the visit of the delegation of the EUACI and the IACAB}}<small>''As of April 13, 2018, Martin Kreutner and Jens Madsen were absent among the IACAB members and participants of the EUACI.''</small></ref>
IACAB professionals perform analysis of anti-corruption efforts in Ukraine in the areas of investigation, criminal persecution and court consideration of high profile corruption cases. The experts create reports based on the results of the their analysis and provide recommendations to improve the efficiency of Ukrainian anti-corruption institutions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uacrisis.org/62754-iaac-castresana-kos |title=Top international anti-corruption experts call to ensure maximum independence of Ukraine's anti-corruption agencies |author= |date=30 November 2017 |website= |publisher=Ukraine crisis media center |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201172834/http://uacrisis.org/62754-iaac-castresana-kos |archive-date=2017-12-01 |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://nazk.gov.ua/news/eksperty-mizhnarodnoyi-antykorupciynoyi-konsultatyvnoyi-rady-iasav-gotuyut-rekomendaciyi |title=Експерти Міжнародної антикорупційної консультативної ради (ІАСАВ) готують рекомендації стосовно покращення правосуддя у справах про топ-корупцію в Україні |author= |date=7 December 2017 |website= |publisher=National agency on corruption prevention |archive-url= Implementing Agency for Integrity Cities concept |author= |date=13 October 2017 |website= |publisher=Ukraine NGO Forum |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> :In a number of Each tent exhibits the various aspects of the top corruption and shows its influence on the lives of regular people.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nv.ua/ukr/ukraine/sekretna-laboratorija-i-test-chi-pidkhodite-vi-dlja-roboti-v-nabu-10-prichin-vidvidati-park-koruptsiji-v-kijevi-2473270.html |title=10 причин відвідати Парк корупції в Києві |author= |date=1 June 2018 |website= |publisher=Новое Время |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614195004/https://nv.ua/ukr/ukraine/sekretna-laboratorija-i-test-chi-pidkhodite-vi-dlja-roboti-v-nabu-10-prichin-vidvidati-park-koruptsiji-v-kijevi-2473270.html |archive-date=2018-06-14 |access-date=2018-06-15 |language=uk |trans-title=10 Reasons to Visit Corruption Park in Kyiv}}</ref> :Additionally, an anti-lecture hall works here, film screenings<ref>{{cite web |url=https://styler.rbc.ua/ukr/zhizn/kieve-startuet-antilektoriy-parka-korruptsii-1528377432.html |title=У Києві стартує антилекторий "Парку корупції": що очікувати від інтерактиву |author= |date=7 June 2018 |website= |publisher=РБК-Україна |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614194934/https://styler.rbc.ua/ukr/zhizn/kieve-startuet-antilektoriy-parka-korruptsii-1528377432.html |archive-date=2018-06-14 |access-date=2018-06-15 |language= |trans-title= In Kiev, the Corruption Parks anti-lecture hall begins: What to expect from an interactive}}</ref> and activities for children take place.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://hromadske.ua/posts/shkola-iunoho-detektyva-i-kazky-pro-khabarnykiv-park-koruptsii-vidkryvaie-prohramu-dlia-ditei |title=Школа юного детектива і казки про хабарників: "Парк корупції" відкриває програму для дітей |author= |date=8 June 2018 |website= |publisher= Hromadske International |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-06-15 |language= |trans-title=School of young detective and fairy tales about bribes: The Corruption Park opens a program for children}}</ref>
== Team == EUACI includes both Ukrainian and foreign professionals:<ref>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/who-we-are/our-team |title=Our team |author= |date= |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> * [[Eka Tkeshelashvili]] – Head of programme * Elena Konceviciute – Senior anti-corruption advisor * Barbara James – Head of administration * Clemence Muller – Senior anti-corruption advisor * Bogdan Boyko – Civil society and local governance expert * Serhiy Derkach – Anti-corruption investigation and prosecution expert * Halyna Kokhan – Anti-corruption and prevention expert * Vitaliy Veselskiy – Information technology expert * Katerina Bazayants – Finance and administration manager * Anastasiia Shevkoplyas – Programme Administrative Associate * Volodymyr Solohub – Communications expert
A Steering Committee was established in order to enable common decision making for implementation of anti-corruption initiatives between the Kingdom of Denmark, EU mission in Ukraine and main institutional beneficiaries. The members of the Steering Committee of the Anti-Corruption Initiative of the European Union in Ukraine are as follows:<ref>{{cite web |url=https://euaci.eu/who-we-are/steering-committee |title= Steering Committee |author= |date= |website= |publisher=EU Anti-corruption Initiative |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> * A Minister from the [[Government of Ukraine|Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]] * National Agency on Corruption Prevention * [[National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine]] * State Financial Monitoring Service of Ukraine * Asset Recovery and Management Agency of Ukraine * [[Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office]] * [[Verkhovna Rada]] Anti-Corruption Committee * Institute of Regional Press Development * Mayors of "Integrity Cities" * [[Embassy of Denmark, Kiev|Ambassador of the Kingdom of Denmark in Ukraine]] * Designated Official from European Union mission in Ukraine
